MainHeading.P: Chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 10.30 a.m.

Speaker.P: It is proposed to take business in the following order: Nos. 3, 7,8,9 and 10. Private Members' Business will be No. 16. I should like to add that it is proposed to interrupt business at 5 p.m. for a statement on the Athens European Council meeting.

Now that the Taoiseach is back with us I should like to ask him if he can be of any assistance to the House, particularly to this party, on the question of the Estimates. We have ordered today item No. 3, Leave to introduce Supplementary Estimates, but we are more concerned about the Book of Estimates for 1984. Our Whip informs us, as a result of discussions, that the only problem preventing the circulation of the Book of Estimates to the Dáil is one of printing. That being so will it be possible for the Taoiseach to arrange to have photocopies of the principal pages of the Estimates circulated to us immediately? Otherwise, as the Taoiseach will understand, we will be given the Book of Estimates next Wednesday or Thursday and, without any opportunity to consider them, the House will be expected to debate them almost immediately. Can the Taoiseach be of any assistance to us on this matter?

The Book of Estimates should be published next Wednesday or Thursday and we will, naturally, make provision for time to debate them. That may involve the Dáil sitting later than would normally be the case. In so far as the question of any advance photocopies being made available is concerned I do not know if that is feasible because of the complexity of the method of preparation for printing. I will certainly inquire into that, and if it is possible to give any advance material or advance version before the printed copy I will try to do so, but I do not have any idea of whether it is technically feasible.

I am grateful to the Taoiseach for that assurance. The Taoiseach will recall that on previous occasions it has been possible to give us photostats of the principal page of each Department. As all Members are aware the Book of Estimates consists of a great deal of detail, but if we could have a week or so in advance a photostat of the principal pages of the Book of Estimates it would be of assistance. The Taoiseach will understand from his own days in Opposition that it is not very practical to expect an Opposition party to debate Estimates produced some hours before. However, I will wait to hear further from the Taoiseach on that matter.

I should like to ask the Taoiseach if he is aware that in this morning's newspapers, and in the media generally, there is what purports to be a leak of an important Government document, and if he can be of any assistance to the House in this matter? As the Taoiseach will understand, it is very undesirable for us in Opposition to be confronted with what purport to be reasonably authoritative statements about important Government policy documents in advance of any publication of those documents by the Government. Allied to that there is a question which I must raise, that there seems to be a deliberate policy from the Department of Education to give exclusive leaks to certain newspapers. There is a very strong suspicion that it is the Minister who is directly responsible for those leaks. I regret to have to say that.
Shame.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Chair allowed the Leader of the Opposition to develop his question on something that appeared in this morning's newspapers, but the Chair is now ruling that this does not arise on the Order of Business.
I submit it is a reasonable question to put to the Taoiseach, to ask him if he is in a position to confirm the statements in the media this morning about what purports to be an official document.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Chair is satisfied that if the Chair was to allow that and every rumour or alleged leak that appeared in the newspapers to be discussed on the Order of Business we would not get anywhere.
I must deplore the ruling of the Chair on that matter. This is very important.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That may be so, but it would be impossible to carry on the business of the House if I permitted that.
I submit that the coverage in this morning's newspapers of what purports to be a significantly important Government document is not a rumour. It is something that the House should take notice of.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Chair has ruled that it does not arise on the Order of Business.
I wish then to make one further point on the Order of Business.

On a point of order, in the course of raising this matter of concern—and which is a matter of concern to all of us—about documents being leaked, an allegation has been made against a Minister. I feel I am entitled to respond to that allegation.
Certainly.
I do not want to be out of order though I would like to say more.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I will deal with the point of order. The Chair feels that if a Member of the House, on the Order of Business, raises a matter which would attract such interest as the document in question, impromptu, without notice, without any limit on the amount of time that may be spent on it, makes a statement, another statement comes from this side of the House, another statement comes from there, the Chair would simply find it impossible to control the business of the House. If it were a debate that was lasting for half an hour, when the half hour was up the Chair would simply bring it to a close. But once a thing like this gets out of hand, the Chair feels, and feels very strongly that it would be impossible to control the business of the House.

Yes, I do not want in any way to impugn your ruling though if you had so allowed I would be prepared to answer. But I feel I am entitled to respond to a specific allegation about a Minister and to confine myself to that.
And I would like to reply to that.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is the problem.
Well, if——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach give way for a second, please? I want to put it this way, that if the Leader of the Opposition or any other Member of the House—he does not have to be the leader of anything—stands up in the morning, if the Chair interrupts him before he has stated what he wants to say then the Chair is told: “Oh, you have not even heard what I wanted to say”. The Chair should get the co-operation of the House. Deputies should make themselves familiar with Standing Orders and the procedures for running this House and debate them. They are being abused day after day.
I would simply like to make a factual statement, I hope, of a non-controversial character, to answer the point made about the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Of course, there is another way, in accordance with Standing Orders, of doing that.
I think, Sir, when an allegation is made about a Member of this House it is normally permitted for that Member to defend himself or herself or to be defended.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I should not have to spell this out of Standing Orders. The person who has been attacked——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Not “attacked”. The Chair should withdraw that.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: ——can, on notice——
Withdraw that.
I resent your use of the word “attack”.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Of course I withdraw it. The person who has been involved in the allegation——
Allegation.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: ——can, on giving notice to the Chair, stand up and give a personal explanation. That is the way to do it.
A Cheann Comhairle——
——or defend a member of my Government. Is the allegation withdrawn?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The allegation was a political allegation.
As one who has been the subject of countless political allegations in this House I think I am entitled to raise one occasionally.
The Leader of the Opposition should withdraw that allegation.
I will not withdraw it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: It was true.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: There is procedure laid down for all of these things. If the House wants me to run the House in accordance with Standing Orders and procedures I will do that; that is what I want to do. There is procedure under which the Minister concerned may, on notice to the Chair, some time during the day stand up and give a personal explanation if that is what is wanted.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: It was a smear.
On a point of order, I just want to put it to you, Sir, that what I am raising is very relevant to the business of the House.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Please, Deputy Haughey; it may be.
I am not making any further point, a Cheann Comhairle. I just want to say, by way of explanation that I raised these two matters——
Well, I am going to say by way of explanation——
——because they put this party at a serious disadvantage in dealing with the business of the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Government wild leaks.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): The people opposite are great people.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Order, I am ruling any further discussion out of order.
I want to raise another matter on the Order of Business.
On a point of order, a Cheann Comhairle, in view of the persistence of the Leader of the Opposition in this matter——

——I wish to state quite simply the following: on the proposal of the Minister for Education the Government have directed an investigation into the question of the leaks of documents from the Department and, in the light of that investigation, will take a decision at their next meeting as to whether the matter needs to be referred to the Garda Síochána. I am entitled to say that in this House in defence of the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The Opposition should now withdraw their statement.
I am glad that the Taoiseach considers the matter of sufficient importance to consider sending it to the Garda Síochána. I am delighted to have that assurance from the Taoiseach.
Hear, hear.
The Opposition should now do the decent thing and withdraw it.
I will await the outcome of the investigation.
A Cheann Comhairle, I wish to move on to another matter.
The Opposition have already assumed what the outcome will be. They should have the grace to withdraw.
There is such a thing as a Minister being responsible for a Department.
I want the Taoiseach to consider a——
Deputy E. O'Keeffe's brains are leaking out anyway.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Order, please. Deputy Haughey on the Order of Business.
If the Minister for Finance can succeed in getting out his Book of Estimates he will be doing a good job.
He should stick to his last and mind his own job.
He let down poor old Deputy John Bruton anyway.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Order.
There is not much order when that kind of allegation is not withdrawn.
I just want to ask the Taoiseach if he will consider, in view of developments inside and outside this House, setting up a judicial inquiry into the affairs of Údarás na Gaeltachta?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That does not arise on the Order of Business and I am so ruling. I am calling Item No. 3.

Might I ask the Taoiseach, on the Order of Business, when the very important Dublin Transport Authority Bill will come before the House, the heads of which Bill went to the parliamentary draftsman well over 12 months ago?

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport (Mr. J. Mitchell) Jim Mitchell
Speaker.P: In due course.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Order, Deputy Leyden.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That does not arise on the Order of Business.
With respect to you, a Cheann Comhairle——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The only way that the Deputy can show respect for the Ceann Comhairle is not by saying it but by obeying his ruling and I am ruling that out of order.
I am not referring to myself, I am referring to the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: It is not in order.
On a point of order, a Cheann Comhairle I have before the House a Private Notice Question——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is another day's work.
You refused it yesterday. I am asking you again today.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am ruling the Deputy out of order. I am calling on Deputy Gene Fitzgerald.
I am asking you, a Cheann Comhairle, if you will allow that question to be answered by the Minister?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy will resume his seat.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: May I ask the Taoiseach, on the Order of Business, what steps the Minister for Agriculture is taking as a result of the closure of Lunhams Bacon Factory in Cork, with the loss of 120 jobs and the damage being done to the pig-producing industry?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: It does not arise on the Order of Business.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Chair will communicate with Deputy Fitzgerald.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Chair will communicate with Deputy Molloy.
With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I wish to raise on the Adjournment——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I wish to tell the Deputy that precedent provides that a Deputy may give notice of one item only on the Adjournment.
You have got me there, Sir.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Well, you got me yesterday, Deputy.
I got the one I wanted anyway.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher

Speaker.P: The Chair will communicate with the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher

I should like to ask the Minister for Justice if he would tell the House when it is intended to take the Committee Stage of the Criminal Justice Bill?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That will not arise until the Second Stage is concluded, and it will be fixed then.
We are coming up to the Christmas recess and I was just wondering at this stage——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: When will the Hours of Work Bill be brought before the House?
Early in the next session.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach not remember that he promised in the House that the Bill would be before us in this session?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is an argument.

I assume there is nothing in Standing Orders to prevent a Deputy, for the fifth occasion, attempting to raise a certain matter on the Adjournment. I propose to raise on the Adjournment the question of the denial to an Irish citizen of her right to speak in the Irish language, such denial having occurred in Mountjoy Prison.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Chair will communicate with Deputy Tunney.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Why the delay in the Hours of Work Bill?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That does not arise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach supplied information to the House that the Bill would be before us this session. I am only asking why.

MainHeading.Title: Air Navigation (Eurocontrol) Bill, 1983: Committee and Final Stages.
MainHeading.P: Question proposed: “That section 1 stand part of the Bill.”

Speaker.P: On this section I should like to emphasise a point which I made on Second Stage, a point to which Deputy Kelly addressed himself on occasion, that is, the question of terminology. In section 1 “determination” means a decision. My thesis and Deputy Kelly's thesis is that if it is a decision it should be called a decision. We should stop wrapping legal terminology in archaicisms which tend to confuse the people for whom the legislation is meant.
Question put and agreed to.
SECTION 2.
Question proposed: “That section 2 stand part of the Bill.”
Section 2 states:
Section 3 of the Act of 1963 is hereby amended by the insertion after subsection (6) of the following subsections:

MainHeading.P: “(7) Persons employed by the Organisation shall enjoy inviolability for all their official papers and documents.”

I must say at this stage that the Minister treated some of my questions on Second Stage in a rather cavalier fashion when we was winding up, and did not take them seriously. I hope to get an opportunity to mention most of them as we go through Committee Stage now. I asked whether this Bill covered military matters and I did not get any comment from the Minister. I may be wrong but as far as I remember, he did not face up to that question and give me an answer. Later I may ask him again.

Why have we this elaborate inviolability for all official papers and documents? I should like to have that teased out. For example, is our Minister for Foreign Affairs so honoured when he goes to Brussels? Are the Commissioners of the EEC so honoured with this inviolability? It seems to me to be breaking a nut with a sledge hammer and to be building up the personnel involved in executive duties in Eurocontrol.
The Director-General of the Agency has to be specially mentioned and wrapped in some form of inviolability. The section states:

(8) The Director-General of the Agency shall enjoy immunity from jurisdiction in respect of acts, other than acts which would constitute a road traffic offence or acts whereby damage is caused by a motor vehicle belonging to, or driven by him, but including words spoken or written.

Immunity from jurisdiction is conferred on the Director-General of Eurocontrol. No satisfactory explanation was given by the Minister of State on Second Stage as to why this should be so. Section 2 also provides:

(9) Representatives of Member States of the Organisation shall, whilst exercising their functions, and in the course of any journey to or from a meeting of the Organisation, enjoy inviolability for their official papers and documents.

This is real cloak and dagger stuff. It seems to me to be special pleading for a very important institution. Is it going too far? Why is it here at all? Apparently it was not thought of in earlier Bills. Has something happened to make it necessary? Are we suspicious that something might happen? I should like the Minister to tease it out for me.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Donnellan) Minister of State at the Department of Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Donnellan)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. Donnellan)
Speaker.P: The privileges and immunities specified in this section are intended to ensure the proper functioning of the organisation and the safeguarding of its interests. It is common practice to extend privileges and immunities enjoyed by senior diplomatic staff to the secretaries and Directors-General of international organisations. The Deputy said some of the points raised by him on Second, Stage were treated by me in a cavalier fashion. That was the Deputy's interpretation, but it was not my intention.

I thank the Minister for his explanation about the general points. On section 2, the Minister simply stated that it was fact that this happened. He did not give any reason why it should happen, or why it should be incorporated in the Bill. I should like to know if it is necessary in relation to this organisation. It is applied to people who, by definition, hold far more important posts in the EEC, or in any of the other international agencies which are now operating, and some people would say proliferating?

Care is taken in section 2 to ensure that everything except a road traffic offence is permissible to the Director-General and that all official papers and documents carried by representatives are especially covered by law. I cannot understand why the section is here. What is the necessity for it, if people holding more important posts have not got it? I know Ambassadors have it. The Minister simply states that it is done. I have not got any reason why it should be done.

It is common practice in organisations of this type. Facilities granted to the staff of Eurocontrol under the new subsection (7) and to representatives of member states of Eurocontrol under the new subsection (9) are solely for the purpose of ensuring full independence in the discharge of their duties and not for their personal benefit. The provision covering inviolability relates to official papers and documents. These provisions are much less than those currently conferred on persons employed in other European and international organisations such as the European Space Agency, European Committees and the United Nations.

In section 2 the new subsection (8) provides that the Director-General shall enjoy immunity from jurisdiction in respect of acts excluding road traffic offences and damage caused by a motor vehicle belonging to him or driven by him, but including words spoken or written. To me the immunity as stated there is much wider than that in section 2, new subsections (7) and (9), which cover official papers and documents. The sky seems to be the limit of immunity for the Director-General. The only matters excluded are road traffic offences or damage caused by a motor vehicle driven by him or belonging to him. I am submitting to the House that the immunity granted is greater than is necessary for the proper functioning of the Director-General of the agency, and for that reason I object to the all-embracing nature of section 2 (8).

There is a difference between sections 7 and 9 and section 8. Section 8 refers to the Director-General of the Agency. The other two sections refer to the staff. The staff have inviolability for papers and documents. It is common practice to extend the privileges enjoyed by senior diplomatic staff to the Secretary and Director-General of international organisations and this is no different from any other organisation.
Does that mean that if the Director-General commits murder in Brussels he has immunity because, as the section reads, it seems to me that will be so?
I would not think so.

He has immunity in respect of acts other than acts which constitute road traffic offences or acts whereby damage was caused by a motor vehicle belonging to or driven by him. It is a very large immunity.
Question put and declared carried.
Sections 3 to 5, inclusive, agreed to.
SECTION 6.

SECTION 7.
Question proposed: “That section 7 stand part of the Bill.”

I do not have the actual detail of what is owed but, as I said, the Eurocontrol centre is continuing to monitor the situation in regard to any necessary legal proceedings.

I know the Minister's style very well and I know he comes from Dunmore. Would he think positively and answer straight and bluntly? Fudging is a disease.
I know it is a disease. They owe $300,000.

The second part of my question is what steps are being taken to recover that money. This is very important. It is relevant to section 7. It was found as a result of experience in the insurance business that some people were not insured while driving cars and caused death or injury to others, and the wisdom garnered from that experience resulted in this House making provision for a fund and the insurance companies had a responsibility to provide that fund. In my opinion it would be important for Eurocontrol to establish such a fund which could be drawn upon when an air company would seriously default.

There is no such fund available, but through the Eurocontrol centre office we can institute proceedings which would be internationally recognised and through which we would recover from whatever country in which they may have operated.

That is important. If they are paying a dime in the dollar to their creditors there is no way we can benefit or recover the moneys lawfully owed to us, and I am asking the Minister would he undertake to write to Eurocontrol and ask them to address themselves to that type of problem.
